Iarlaith Review - Empires and Puzzles Hero Strategy Guide

Meet Iarlaith, the Garrison Guard who turns a single target into a damage magnet. With his 'Ring Around the Rosie' skill, he links enemies together in a deadly dance of shared suffering. Discover why this Fast mana sniper is more than just a pretty face in our comprehensive review.
Iarlaith: The Stylish Swordsman Who Makes Enemies Share Their Pain
Iarlaith: The Red Rogue Who Makes Your Problems Everyone's Problems

Iarlaith, the "Stylish Swordsman," dances onto the battlefield as a member of the Garrison Guards family. Released in early 2025, this 5-star Fire hero brings a devious twist to the standard sniper archetype. While he hits one target hard, his true power lies in making that unfortunate soul suffer for the mistakes of their teammates. He's a Fast mana Rogue who specializes in focusing damage, making him a nightmare for key enemy heroes. Think of him as the guy who reminds the tank that yes, they
feel it when their flank gets punched in the face.

Visually, Iarlaith is a breath of fresh spring air in a game often dominated by grimdark warriors and eldritch horrors. He sports a flower crown that would make any Coachella attendee jealous and wields a massive, curved sword with the grace of a dancer. The contrast between his armored, martial stance and the delicate floral accessories suggests a warrior who appreciates the finer things in life—like perfectly executing a tactical strike while smelling like daisies. It’s a refreshingly lighthearted design that belies the nasty things he does to enemy health bars.

When looking at Iarlaith's stats (1200 Attack, 1172 Defense, 2173 Health), we have to view them through the lens of the rapid power creep of late 2025. Compared to the titans of stats released in December 2025 (who are pushing 1300+ Attack and Defense), Iarlaith is starting to look a bit "vintage" despite being less than a year old. His stats are respectable—certainly enough to keep him viable—but he no longer sits at the apex of the food chain. He relies more on his skill mechanics than raw stat superiority to win fights these days.
Special Skill: Ring Around the Rosie
"Ring Around the Rosie" is a deceptively simple name for a skill that can absolutely dismantle a defense team.
First, he deals 600% damage to a single target at Fast speed. Even with slightly older stats, 600% is a massive multiplier that will leave a dent.
This is the crown jewel. The target receives 100% of all damage their

take for 3 turns. This effectively turns any subsequent Area of Effect (AoE) attack into a nuke on the primary target. If you hit the whole enemy team with a strong AoE while this effect is active, Iarlaith's target takes their own share PLUS the share of four other teammates. It’s a "delete button" for whichever enemy you choose.
A nice cherry on top, increasing all damage received by all enemies by +8% per cast (up to +80%). This ramps up the pressure in longer fights.
Let's crunch some numbers to see why this flower-crowned fencer is dangerous.
Fast. He charges in 8 tiles (7 with minimal mana support), allowing him to set up his debuff early in the match.
1200 Attack x 600% = ~7200 raw damage value (before defense mitigation).
Let's say you mark the enemy Tank. You then fire a hero who hits all enemies for 300% damage.
takes the damage dealt to the Left Flank, Right Flank, Left Wing, and Right Wing.
Effectively, the Tank just took a 1500% damage hit from your AoE hero (300% x 5 sources).
This mathematical absurdity is why Iarlaith is terrifying in the right hands.
Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities
The Garrison Guards are known for holding the line, and Iarlaith is no exception.
The Garrison Guard family bonus typically involves spawning Mega Minions, which adds a layer of survivability and extra meat shielding to the team.
This is a top-tier passive. In a meta filled with mana cutters and controllers, Iarlaith ensures his Fast speed stays Fast. He can't be slowed down by the likes of Roughian & Nurgib or the Neema.
Cleansing Wither effects every 4 turns is a solid utility passive, keeping his stats healthy against heroes that try to whittle them down permanently.
is simple and effective. Since Iarlaith is a damage dealer first and foremost, boosting his base attack directly scales up that juicy 600% snipe.
Upon release, Iarlaith was compared heavily to Torben due to the damage-link mechanic. He was seen as a tactical nuke, capable of removing threats that were otherwise hard to kill.

As we approach the end of 2025, pure damage dealers often struggle to stay relevant if they don't offer utility. Iarlaith's stats have fallen behind the 1300+ Attack curve of the latest "Titan Hunter" and "Three Kingdoms" releases.
Despite the stat gap, Iarlaith remains

in offense. His mechanic is unique enough that it bypasses the need for sheer stats. He is a force multiplier. As long as you have other heavy hitters to pair with him, he can facilitate kills that no other sniper can. He has moved from a "must-have carry" to a "specialized combo piece," but an incredibly effective one.
As of now, Iarlaith does not have a costume. He is relying on his base swagger and flower crown to get the job done.
Iarlaith is a Rogue, which gives him a chance to dodge direct damage. This survivability is key for a fast sniper who needs to stay alive to cast.
Maximizes the 600% hit and the bleed damage from Rogue talents.
Leaves him squishy, potentially dying before he can fire.
he places, not just his initial hit. Staying alive to cast "Ring Around the Rosie" is more important than doing 50 more damage with the sword.
path is recommended. The magic happens when he lands the debuff and your
heroes follow up. He needs to survive to set the table.
The damage transfer mechanic allows you to bypass high defense or damage reduction on a specific target by hitting their softer allies.
Fast mana means he keeps pace with the fastest offensive teams.
Immune to mana reduction means he is reliable.
The +8% stack helps the whole team grind down tough defenses over time.

The damage link is a status effect (usually uncleansable on similar heroes, but check specific interactions—Torben's was uncleansable, Iarlaith's description implies standard mechanics unless specified otherwise). If the enemy cleanses it, his main gimmick is gone.
He is good on his own, but
only when paired with AoE damage. Without follow-up, he's just a standard sniper.
Falling slightly behind the bleeding edge of the meta.
This is his home. He allows you to dismantle defensive formations by picking off the most dangerous hero (like a reviver or heavy hitter) using AoE damage.
The damage stack (+8% per hit) is valuable for high scores, and his high single-target damage contributes well.
Great for boss waves where you want to kill the boss quickly while clearing the minions/adds.
The key to using Iarlaith is
Iarlaith + 2x Fast/Average AoE Hitters (e.g., Brimstone, Gestalt, or newer Hit-All heroes).
Iarlaith marks the priority target. The AoE hitters fire. The marked target takes 3-4x the damage and evaporates.
Iarlaith + Guardian Kong (or similar dispeller/buffer) + Heavy Hitter.
Use Iarlaith to soften up and mark a target, then unleash tile damage and specials. The damage link works on tile damage too if you can cascade into the other enemies!
Monks/Clerics who can resist the status effect, or heroes who provide Ailment Immunity (like Hathor or Aron). If the "Ring Around the Rosie" debuff doesn't stick, Iarlaith loses 50% of his value.
Snipers. Pairing Iarlaith with 4 other snipers is a waste. His debuff wants you to hit

If you pulled Iarlaith early, congratulations! You have a "delete button." Focus on leveling him and pairing him with heroes that hit multiple enemies, even if they are 4-star heroes like Colen or Scarlett. He will carry you through map stages by letting you kill bosses by hitting their minions.

Iarlaith is a tactical tool. He isn't the mindless "fire and forget" nuke that some newer heroes are. Use him to break stall teams or to snipe out annoying tanks that have high defense but low HP allies. He is worth the Limit Break if you enjoy combo-heavy playstyles, but if you prefer raw, mindless power, you might find setting up his combo tedious compared to just firing 3 OP AoE heroes.
The community reaction to Iarlaith was generally positive, highlighting his utility over raw power.
"Quintin on steroids... 15 coin pulls got me nothing…followed up with a 10 pull which got me Iarlaith!"
Another user drew the inevitable comparison:
"Looks like a good hero... he is a 'save as' version of Torben."
There was some debate about his artwork, with one forum user brutally stating:
"Daemon wins. The art for this is too disjointed and kinda blurry."
A savvy tactician pointed out his synergy:
"Especially useful against Glass heroes. Pairing with Beowulf is a joy."

Iarlaith is the kind of hero that makes you feel smart when you use him correctly. There is a profound satisfaction in hitting an enemy on the left wing and watching the tank in the center drop dead because of the damage link. While his stats may not be the highest in the game anymore, his unique mechanic ensures he will have a seat at the table for a long time. He turns the enemy team's existence against them.
A tactical mastermind's dream and a solid addition to any red roster.
